ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Gained some diffuse knowledge on ticks, cheeses and a few select elements. Some writing skill was developed;however, only in the sense that I now have 2 papers worth more writing experience.
I felt I learned most when other students gave presentations about their elements, because I learned so much about human health.
A better understanding of minerals and its effect on human health. This course gave me a different perspective to my every day life.
I learned about one element from the periodic table and I learned how to properly taste cheese.
Understanding of basic roles of elements in the human body. Exposure to various fields related to geochemistry.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The classes have a relaxing atmosphere and requires a low work commitment On the other side, it has no structure. This could be improved by giving it some structure. Assignments were never given back so one had no idea of the grades one was receiving. This could be improved by giving assignments back.

I did not know my grade at all through out the course, which was a weakness. The class also lacked a little structure. We mainly had guest lectures, which were interesting, but I would have liked to see the professor teach more.
This course was great. I really enjoyed it, especially the guest lecturers. The only suggestions I have are to offer more feedback on class presentations and papers.

This was a pretty awful course. It was mostly bearable because it did not require a very large amount of work, but students were extremely unengaged and nobody in the class really seemed to care at all for the class.

Strengths: Student-initiated projects on topics that are interesting to you. Weaknesses: The topics felt random and not integrated. There was no feedback throughout the semester on the quality of our work. The papers felt long and lacked guidance.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, if your workload and intellectual capacity is already maxed from other courses, you would want to take it as this course offers none of those.
Yes, I would recommend this course to someone interested in a science seminar.

I would not recommend. Take it if you are looking for a science credit and can't stand actual science but don't mind writing a few research papers. If you actually enjoy science, you wont find it here. The course consisted entirely of guest lecturers and student presentations, which were all thoroughly un-engaging, with the exception of our cheese tasting on the final class. That is the only section that I actually remember the material from.
A relatively easy, writing-based geochemistry class. I would take this class if you are looking for a straight-forward way to fulfill requirements
